description:
Hepatitis D virus (HDV) is a small, circular, single-stranded RNA virus that belongs to the family Deltaviridae. HDV is considered a defective virus, as it requires the presence of hepatitis B virus (HBV) for its replication and propagation.

HDV-4 is one of the four major genotypes of HDV, which are classified based on the genetic diversity of the viral genome. HDV-4 is primarily found in certain regions of Asia, including Japan, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Compared to other HDV genotypes, HDV-4 is associated with more severe liver disease and a higher rate of progression to cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

The genome of HDV-4 consists of approximately 1,680 nucleotides and encodes a single protein, the hepatitis delta antigen (HDAg), which plays a crucial role in the viral life cycle. HDV-4 has distinct genetic features and mutations that differentiate it from other HDV genotypes, which can influence its pathogenicity and transmission dynamics.

Understanding the characteristics of HDV-4 is important for the development of effective diagnostic tools, antiviral therapies, and public health strategies to prevent and manage hepatitis D infections in regions where this genotype is prevalent.
